translated: The Mansion Chapter
The Divine Man’s Mansion🔽The Great Chariot Chapter
The Great Chariot Mansion

analyzed: sahassa yuttam haya vāhanam subha  āruyhimam sandanam nekacitta
translated: “A beautiful chariot yoked with a thousand horses,🔽I rode this golden chariot with many thoughts,
Circling around the park grounds,
Like Purindada, lord of beings, like Vāsava.

analyzed: sovaṇṇa mayāḥ te ratha kubbarāḥ ubho
translated: The two chariot poles are made of gold,
With fruits and branches, very well-connected;
Well-made with the best of human jewels,
It shines like the moon on the fifteenth day.
This chariot is covered with a golden net,
Adorned with many different jewels;
With the sound of the chariot and the beautiful voice,
It shines with the hands and arms holding the yak-tail fans.
These spokes are created by the mind,
Adorning the middle of the chariot’s wheels;
These spokes are created by the mind of the thousand kings,
With the radiance of a thousand lightning bolts.
This chariot is covered with many thoughts,

analyzed: puthū ca nemī ca sahassa rasiko
translated: With many rims and a thousand spokes;
Their sound is heard with a beautiful form,
Like the sound of a five-part musical instrument being played.

original: Sirasmiṁ cittaṁ maṇicandakappitaṁ,🔽Sadā visuddhaṁ ruciraṁ pabhassaraṁ;
analyzed: sirasmim cittam maṇi canda kappita  sadā visuddham ruciram pabhassara
translated: The horse’s head is adorned with a jewel crest,🔽Always pure, lovely, and radiant;
Very much connected with golden ornaments,
It shines forth like a cat’s eye jewel crest.

analyzed: ime ca vāḷī maṇi canda kappitā
translated: And these horses are adorned with jewel crests,

analyzed: āroha kambū su javā brahu upamā
translated: With high shoulders, straight, and like Brahmā;
Brahmā is great, strong, and very swift,
And so they neigh in accordance with your mind.
And all these four in unison,

original: Mano tavaññāya tatheva siṁsare;🔽Samaṁ vahantī mudukā anuddhatā,
analyzed: mano tavaññāya tathā iva sisare  samam vahantī mudukā anuddhatā
translated: And so they neigh in accordance with your mind;🔽They carry evenly, gently, and without agitation,
The best of horses, fragrant and delightful.

original: Dhunanti vagganti patanti cambare,🔽Abbhuddhunantā sukate piḷandhane;
analyzed: dhunanti vagganti patanti cambare  su kate piḷandhane
translated: They shake, neigh, and prance about,🔽And when they are well-groomed and well-fed,
Their neighing is heard with a pleasant sound,

analyzed: pañcaṅgikam tūriyam iva ppavādita  rathassa ghosaḥ a piḷandhanāna ca
translated: Like a five-part musical instrument being played.🔽The sound of the chariot and the creaking of the axle,
The sound of the hooves and the slapping,
The pleasant sound of the well-controlled one is heard,
With various arrangements of Gandhabba music.

analyzed: rathe ṭhitā tā miga manda locanā
translated: Standing in the chariot, those deer-eyed ones,
Āḷāra’s daughters, smiling, speaking pleasantly,
With nets of beryl, with their own radiance,
Honoured by gods, Gandhabbas, Suras and Aggis.

analyzed: tāḥ ratta ratta ambara pīta vāsasā
translated: Those who are clothed in red, yellow and orange,
With large eyes, with eyes of delight,

analyzed: kule su jātā su tanū su cimhitā
translated: Well born in families, with good bodies, well adorned,
Standing in the chariot, with hands raised in respectful salutation.

analyzed: tā kambu keyūra dharā su vāsasā  su majjhimā ūru thanū upapannā
translated: Those who wear conch bracelets, anklets, and are well dressed,🔽With well-rounded thighs, with well-formed calves,
With round fingers, with beautiful faces, with good complexions,
Standing in the chariot, with hands raised in respectful salutation.
Others with beautiful plaits, with hair like the lotus and jasmine,
Evenly divided, with a shining appearance,
Following you, delighting in your mind,
Standing in the chariot, with hands raised in respectful salutation.🔽Those who are covered in lotus and jasmine,
Adorned, perfumed with the essence of sandalwood,
Following you, delighting in your mind,

original: Rathe ṭhitā pañjalikā upaṭṭhitā.🔽Tā māliniyo padumuppalacchadā,
analyzed: rathe ṭhitā pañjalikā upaṭṭhitā  tāḥ māliniyaḥ paduma uppala chadā
translated: Standing in the chariot, with hands raised in respectful salutation.🔽Those who are covered in lotus and jasmine,
Adorned, perfumed with the essence of sandalwood,
Following you, delighting in your mind,
Standing in the chariot with hands raised in reverence.
The ornaments on their necks,
On their hands and heads as well,
Illuminating all ten directions,
Like the radiant moon in autumn.
Shaken by the force of the wind,
The garlands and ornaments on their arms,
Emitting a delightful, pure, and beautiful sound,
Heard by all the wise.
Standing in the middle of the pleasure ground,

original: Rathā ca nāgā tūriyāni ca saro;
analyzed: rathā ca nāgā tūriyāni ca saro
translated: The chariots, elephants, and the sound of musical instruments,
Delight the Lord of the Devas himself,
Like a lute with lotus-leaf hands.
In these many beautiful lutes,
With delightful sounds that bring joy to the heart,
As they are played, the celestial nymphs
Dance on lotus flowers, well-trained.

original: Yadā ca gītāni ca vāditāni ca,
analyzed: yadā ca gītāni ca vāditāni ca
translated: When the songs, musical instruments,
And dances come together in one place,

analyzed: atha itthā naccanti atha itthā accharā
translated: Then there they dance, then there the celestial nymphs,
Illuminating both sides of the assembly.
You rejoice, awakened by the sound of musical instruments,
As you are worshipped like the thunderbolt weapon.
Among these many lutes, so harmonious,
You delight in the beautiful sound.
What deed did you do in the past,

original: Manussabhūto purimāya jātiyā;🔽Uposathaṁ kaṁ vā tuvaṁ upāvasi,
analyzed: manussa bhūtaḥ purimāya jātiyā  uposatham kam vā tuvam upāvasi
translated: While a human being in a previous life?🔽What observance did you observe?
What practice of the Dhamma did you delight in?
This is not the result of a deed done by you,
Or of observing the observance in the past;
This is your great power of supernormal power,
By which you shine forth among the assembly of gods.

original: Dānassa te idaṁ phalaṁ,🔽atho sīlassa vā pana;
analyzed: dānassa te idam phala  atho sīlassa vā pana
translated: Is this the fruit of generosity,🔽Or is it of virtue?
Or is it of paying homage with folded hands?
Please tell me this when asked.”

analyzed: saḥ deva puttaḥ atta mano  moggallānena pucchito
translated: That god, being pleased,🔽When asked by Moggallāna,
Answered the question,
“This is the fruit of that deed.”
“One who has conquered the senses, the Buddha, the mind’s supreme friend,🔽The supreme human, Kassapa, the foremost person on the path,

analyzed: avāpuḥ antam amatassa dvāra 🔽devātidevam sata puñña lakkhaṇa
translated: Opening the door to the deathless,🔽The god above gods, with the thirty-two marks of merit,
I saw the elephant who had crossed the great flood,🔽Resembling a golden mountain peak.
Having seen him, I quickly became pure-minded,
Having seen him, the one who had the banner of good speech.

analyzed: tam anna pānam athavā api cīvara
translated: I gave him a drink and a robe,
Pure, excellent, and endowed with taste;
While I was collecting flowers in my own house,
I established it with an unattached mind.

analyzed: tam anna pānena ca cīvarena ca
translated: With a drink and a robe,

analyzed: khajjena bhojjena ca sa ayanena ca
translated: With food, drink, and refreshments;
Having satisfied the supreme one among two-legged beings,
I rejoice in the city of the gods like Indra.

original: Etenupāyena imaṁ niraggaḷaṁ,🔽Yaññaṁ yajitvā tividhaṁ visuddhaṁ;
analyzed: etena upāyena imam niraggaḷa  yaññam yajitvā tividham
translated: By this means, having performed this open-air sacrifice,🔽Sacrificed the threefold pure sacrifice;
Having abandoned my human abode,
I rejoice in the city of the gods like the moon.
Desiring longevity, beauty, happiness, and strength,
The sage should establish with an unattached mind

analyzed: annañca pānañca bahum su saṅkhata  patiṭṭhapetabbam asaṅga mānase
translated: Much food and drink, well-prepared,🔽The excellent form,
In this world or the next,

original: Buddhena seṭṭho va samo va vijjati;
analyzed: buddhena seṭṭhaḥ va samaḥ va vijjati
translated: There is no one equal to the Buddha, much less a superior one.
He has gone to the highest offering of offerings,

analyzed: puññatthikānam vipula phala esinam ti  mahā ratha vimānam
translated: For those seeking abundant fruit for their merit.”🔽The Great Chariot Discourse is the fourteenth.
The fifth chapter is called “The Great Chariot.”
The summary:
The frog, Revati, the parasol,
Kakkaṭa, the doorkeeper,
Two to be done, two needles,
Three nāgas, and two chariots;
The first chapter of men is proclaimed.
The third recitation section.
